newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine unions, business to meet Menem Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Argentine unions, business to meet Menem Tuesday.

text.p: Argentina's President Carlos Menem will meet heads of the powerful Group of Eight (G-8) business lobbies and the CGT labor federation Tuesday for talks on key labor market reforms, officials said Monday.
Menem will receive the business and union leaders at 1900 local time (2200 GMT), government officials told the government-controlled Telam news agency.
The meeting was originally scheduled to take place Monday and be chaired by Cabinet Chief Jorge Rodriguez. Telam quoted no reason for the postponement.

Menem tried to decree wide-ranging measures to liberalize Argentina's labor market late last year but his move was strongly opposed by unions and eventually rejected by the courts as unconstitutional. The government then began talks with unions and business, but the G-8 dropped out before Menem finally signed a preliminary accord with the CGT.
Menem met both sides a week ago and told them to narrow their differences before seeing him again.
Menem's Chief of Staff Alberto Kohan told local radio that unions and business were willing to talk.
"There is good will on both sides for a meeting," Kohan said, adding, "of course each is defending their own interests."

The government hopes an agreement between all parties will allow it to pass labor market reforms quickly and begin to reduce Argentina's 17.4-percent unemployment rate. But business complains that the agreement between the government and unions was an ineffectual shadow of the original reforms.
